body:
Comment 26 by **jz4082**: 
Yah, it looks like linux (the guest os) recognizes just 1 core. 

$ cat /proc/cpuinfo
processor	: 0
vendor_id	: GenuineIntel
cpu family	: 6
model		: 23
model name	: Intel(R) Core(TM)2 Duo CPU     T9400  @ 2.53GHz
stepping	: 10
cpu MHz		: 593.976
cache size	: 6144 KB
fdiv_bug	: no
hlt_bug		: no
f00f_bug	: no
coma_bug	: no
fpu		: yes
fpu_exception	: yes
cpuid level	: 5
wp		: yes
flags		: fpu vme de pse tsc msr mce cx8 apic mtrr pge mca cmov pat pse36 clflush mmx
fxsr sse sse2 constant_tsc up pni monitor ssse3
bogomips	: 1187.95
clflush size	: 64
cache_alignment	: 64
address sizes	: 36 bits physical, 48 bits virtual
power management:


I've been having second thoughts on the root cause of the slowness though. I recently
read that cygwin had a problem where forking on windows was really slow for a while, and
although vbox isn't exactly cygwin, i wouldn't be surprised if there were a similar
issue.  And plus there have been complaints about the state of vbox ever since it was
acquired. 

It's enough to make me throw my hands up and consider the alternatives. I haven't
entirely made a decision yet, but I'm considering just reinstalling linux to work
directly off my machine now.
